KBjW1hOT-Bq9cnEN8ElB1g.text: Excellent find in an ocean of humanity. I had my doubts as I passed Ripley's Believe It or Not from Picadilly Station, but I was totally satisfied with the restaurant. For £7.15 I had a great meal with mint tea. Both delicious and a substantial amount of food.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. All this for 7.15!

grvxf-EdNSWPY0X565WvFQ.text: Food was great for the most part. The mint, apple, ginger lemonade was great. Service was subpar. We were asked to move to a table of two to let people sit down. We were almost done as well. They gave us desserts on the house even though we ordered them but it was still rude. We agreed because it was cold outside. Also, we saw them giving preference to some customers who arrived later.

oGWHN8thZ1IG82u9QVbH8w.text: This was Yalla Yalla's first restaurant, it is tucked on a side street in soho and is very small. This isn't a bad thing though, there are about 6 tables and a counter fills one wall; full of appetising food! Famed for 'Beirut street food' Yalla Yalla is rapidly expanding across London. My favorite mezzes are the calamari - really crispy and with a few whitebait and prawns thrown in! and of course the falafel and hummus. Delicious!

LsqPCpxv77nzUVcxrXJQzA.text: I'm kind of confused that people seem to be marking this place down for being small.  If you want to eat there at the weekend, don't rely on just walking up and waiting - make a reservation.  They're small and they're popular: you can't fault them for that.I had an admittedly slightly odd first experience of this place, as I was taking a big group of people there and they opened the restaurant specially.  The service was great, not least because we were looked after by the lovely couple that owns the place.The food was delicious, fresh and interesting.  It's amazing value considering the quality.  Couldn't really fault it...

7exm00xZcEbjvNeD1lRTWw.text: Ok, the food is delicious here, but is it worth the hour plus wait on a weekend night?  Erm.  I have better things to be doing with my time than queuing for dinner, especially when you have to wait right there, and can't pop around the corner for a pint.Here's a little secret, though.  Skip the line, walk 5 minutes north across Oxford Street, and go to the Yalla Yalla in Fitzrovia.  Same amazing food, bigger kitchen, and bigger tables in a bigger yet still cozy space. We walked in on a Saturday night at 7:30 and there were plenty of seats available.

GAmytMLwtpu3R1tflqJRAA.text: This is delicious, quick, cheap, and fun! There are tons of options and it's best if you go with friends and share lots of things! I highly recommend the Arayes - delicious! The cocktails are really good too, but more expensive than the food. Super close to Oxford and Tottenham! It can get pretty busy but it's worth it!

GgzsVUqqGr1pzqqmnhC1-A.text: Phenomenal Lebanese food. Discovered Yalla Yalla a few years ago, and now I make sure it's added to every London trip. There is nothing in the US that I have ever experienced that is like Yalla Yalla. A savory experience unrivaled.

E4CSivulXwVQhX4Ovh11lw.text: Seats less than 20, pretty nice little spot in a small sketchy alley right in Soho.Hummus Shawarma with lamb slices &  Fattoush EVERY time.

WSVeo_Y-yyZ67cLIIieWUA.text: Beirut Street Food? What? I randomly walked by this place recently when it was closed on a bank holiday and had to go back to check out the food. I'm happy to report that this tiny hidden gem on Green's Court in Soho is fantastic! It's a small sit down cafe with cute wooden tables and pillows made out of middle eastern scarves turned hipster fashion signature turned cafe decoration. They've got a counter filled with seriously droolworthy snacks and desserts, from multiple kinds of baklava to a selection of meat, spinach, or cheese pastries, to some incredible looking tarts like fig, apple cinnamon, and rosemary.  Then they've got a kitchen hidden somewhere that turns out fabulous hot dishes at great prices. We sat right next to the counter, where the smell of the desserts was overwhelmingly delicious. I think i basically stuck my face in them to inhale the scent, so my apologies if you get a nose print in your pastry next time. We ordered a bunch of different things whose names I can't remember - a really fresh, lemony, zesty salad of greens and crunchy pita chips , a spinach pastry, a kibbe appetizer of small chunks of lamb, and a fantastic slow cooked lamb casserole with rice where you could cut the meat with a fork. Yum. I also had a big pot of mint tea and they brought ample warmed pitas to dip in the olive oil they have bottled on every table. We chatted with the owners, who let me try a baklava for free. They just opened and will hopefully soon have a liquor license as well as tables outside. They're super nice and the food is fantastic. I will definitely be going back soon to try everything else on the menu. Best of all, we were stuffed with the four dishes and the grand total was under 20 pounds. You can pop in for a sit-down meal or grab a tasty snack to go. Beirut street food...who knew?

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. The menu, the counter, and delicious things on the counter
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Mmmmmm fig tart
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Yalla Yalla from the outside

jXG-v3BXOccp-_lkcz6m1A.text: The wait was long but worth it! Come prepared to wait for a table and wait quite a while for your food. It's made to order and worth the wait. I ordered baba ganoush, chicken shawarma, both of which where delicious. The service was great as well!

7X9HptaRk3ZJjT6cJwgOXQ.text: I'm visiting London from NYC and I have to say that Yalla Yalla is one of the best Mediterranean places I have been to! It's a very cute little restaurant in Soho, London. If you're looking for warm pita an delicious hummus, this is your place!

f6DQU9-EJoEKxLkUgYc9Qw.text: I was expecting a lot from Yalla Yalla given the write-ups here but left slightly disappointed. The thing that struck me most about their Soho branch was its small size. This meant that every available counter space was occupied with food or utensils and forced the staff to make their way around the branch in a strange balletic routine requiring them to interact in some way with whatever they were moving past at that moment e.g. squeezing round the counter, moving something out the way, taking something further along in its preparation, take order etc. I ordered a Lamb Shawarma and a freshly squeezed orange juice for takeaway. The orange juice was pretty decent, but the Shawarma seemed rather ordinary. Then there was the price - I didn't get much change from a tenner, which surprised me somewhat for takeaway food (while accepting that freshly squeezed orange juice is pretty pricey whenever you get it).However, the customers eating in seemed content and the food they had looked pretty appetising. So I'll definitely be back to try the eat-in experience and may revise my rating then.

HDXrWALM_qiK-ocv0kpOqQ.text: This small restaurant  is a very good place to pop up for a bite to eat as well as to order food for delivery. There is nothing special about the interior but the atmosphere and service are great and the prices are very affordable. I have ate there several times and have never been disappointed. If you like Middle Eastern cuisine served in a welcoming surrounding you should visit the Yalla Yalla.

wV7HKWpXZI3YjvuCpVzOlA.text: Service is a total joke here, takes them about 4 minutes to do what amounts to heating up a wrap from a pile probably made 5 hours ago judging from the size of it. 4/5 members of staff, only one doing the utterly menial task at hand

RVqpGp1C5NcUXI7oQ-fWZA.text: Really nice small Beirut Street Food/ Middle Eastern Restaurant.If you fancy a meal here, I recommend booking in advance, it's so small and popular.The 2 negatives I have with the place are: there are no mixed Meze starters to pick, which means you have to pick independant dishes to make up your own Mixed Meze. This is fine but it means the prices are high!  I also thought the hommous was pretty expensive -- for what it is....I don't mind paying for good food but I just think for what you actually get the prices are taking the P...I guess it is Soho though so people will pay.If you really fancy Middle Eastern food and have a bit of time, Edgware Road is full of great restaurants/ Take Aways at much more reasonable prices.

_Y2JelTbV0qSrnDg6Cw89w.text: Maybe in the two years since I've last been to Yalla Yalla I'm really no longer concerned with emerging as a Greasy McFatterson after eating its meze. Because my most recent visit was a revelation of everything oily and delicious. The baba ganoush was simply the most fabulous taste explosion of culinary prowess that ever was or ever will be. In London or in Beirut. Usually, I don't like baba ganoush. In fact, I've never eaten baba ganoush anywhere and thought, 'Hot damn, that is some fine baba ganoush.'But I ate the baba ganoush at Yalla Yalla and thought, 'Hot damn, that is some fine baba ganoush. Bring on the pomegranate seeds!' And I proceeded to eat it all so quickly that my dining companion didn't even have a chance. Not. a. chance.So I'm jumping on this Yummy Yummy bandwagon. Yalla Yalla is the place to be, especially for a late-night, post-bar, Soho meze dinner. Sure, there are loads of places for you to eat in Soho, but don't be a sucker. Everyone needs a bit more pomegranate in her life.

_DrvDqiCjzVLLEv-MmtNNQ.text: Being jewish, having had more than once this kind of food, I must say I was a bit worried about this place. We went for a friend's birthday who had spent a few months in Beirut, and his expectations were high but everyone was looking forward to this!It was quite a long wait for lunch as the restaurant was packed! Always thought that was a good sign. The birthday boy, who knew this a lot better than most of us ordered everything and may I just say, every thing looked mouth watering!The choice came down to him and every single item was just gorgeous, so tasty and just so fresh. It was one of the best meals I've had in London so far. Yes it is a little greasy but this is authentic street food and that's just the way it is! I highly recommend it, you'll love it!

UF89KHGr_gJN1bMXStgPXQ.text: Literally stumbled upon this place whilst walking around Soho one afternoon. The bread is super light & fluffy & the chicken taouk is fabulous along with the labneh yogurt sauce. very very small place but great it's halal

WgWLPXZcD7oFUK5j0TWDnA.text: What a great place!  Bustling and busy, on the small side with communal tables that make it feel  like a big happy community.  There's a chaos to the way they do things here, but it works out just fine.  They have full meals here, but you'd be best served, especially in a group, to just order to mezzes each and then share.  The little plates are not that little, and pack a powerful array of choice and flavour.  And that's no exaggeration; I was burping up garlic all afternoon, and for all you people suddenly turned off, shut it!  That's a good thing.  I absolutely loved their little lamb pastries, the sausages were great and the babghanouj and grilled lamb hummus were legendary.  All to be had with puffy pita that you sop it all up with.  yum.  Be warned though, the place is popular, and rightly so, even early in the week for lunch.  I've yet to try their takeout schwarmas (giant pile of them at the counter), as well as traditional sweets but I'll put that to right soon.

a28w8WK6YPFcAEdW0QUABw.text: I've been here twice now, and I'd say it's a solid 3.5. I'm bumping it up to a 4 because the second visit was much improved on the first. First off, the location is great, and this smaller branch of what is now a 2-restaurant 'mini-chain' is definitely cute and charming. Unfortunately, they don't take bookings, which means you inevitably have to wait. On our most recent visit, the food was very good- the hummus and baba ganoush were especially tasty, as was the moussaka. I was sort of disappointed by the tabbouleh, which was light on the bulgar wheat and heavy on the vinegar. Our server was super friendly and attentive despite the place being crammed as it always is. I think the prices here are fair, but it's not an exceptionally great deal.Definitely a solid choice for Lebanese in the area, provided you are willing to wait for your table.

aQjykdNqyyMv8chWu8_ttA.text: My wife had the idea of visiting this hidden restaurant in Soho on a night after work. It was full and buzzing when we got there, so we got a beer each to drink while we waited outside.Once seated, we rattled off a list of what we wanted, but as our list kept growing, the waitress told us it would be too much.  I laugh when this happens because we are excited about the dishes that sound good, but we neglect how much we are able to fit in!  It turns out she was right - after our meal, I was pretty full and satisfied.We got a few starter sized dishes: baba gannouj (eggplant dip with pommegranite), rakkat (chicken wrapped in crispy pastry) and fattoush (salad).  We also had some main-sized dishes: kreidis meshoue and kafta meshoue (king prawns and lamb mince). My favourites were the baba gannouj and the kafta meshoue. The salad dressing was a bit too vinegary for me and the king prawn dish was difficult to tackle.I enjoyed the atmosphere of the restaurant and it seems like a good place to catch up with friends.

dW1kRJuRw2UoqeFGlDUQSQ.text: HOMMOS SHAWARMA-Chickpea purée topped with marinated thin slices of lamb fillet.SOUJOC- Homemade spicy Lebanese sausages with tomato, parsley and lemon juice.KAFTA MESHOUE- Charcoal grilled spiced minced lamb, onion and parsley skewers, grilled tomato, sumac onion salad. I loved everything here except there was a bit too much lemon juice in our soujoc. Hommos was smooth and delicious. Service was super friendly and efficient even during the workday lunch time rush. The minute we walked in, everyone was very welcoming.

HgLy_slKJXZXUhC2_r4hXQ.text: Cosy, cafe-style interior, mainly on low stools and small tables. You would struggle to get a large group in here.Now the food - D e l i c i o u s. Fresh greens, lightly fried kibbeh and falafel, mezze including baba ghanoush and hummus that taste homemade with extra virgin olive oil. Top that off with an assortment of bite size desserts and Lebanese pastries, fresh mint tea and shisha.Don't miss this place.

6l-r5yt4XP3SkeYnFm20nQ.text: Came here for lunch and had a proper feast. The baba ganoush and fatoush were great.  The seafood dishes were yummy. The place is small and cozy. Not a lot of seating room. The mint tea was refreshing. Overall, a great spot and highly recommend it.

_JjLCOW_6tIPhEA3tN_ACg.text: This was my first time eating Lebanese and it was great!! We tried around six of their starter dishes and they were all delicious. I really enjoyed this restaurant. Even though it was a tight space, they were nice and willing to accommodate 6 people. I will definitely be coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Delicious fattoush!

uWyO3WFeOBXOrUGvR3R3WQ.text: Awesome food. Small restaurant - intimate. Definitely have the falafel and the mint tea!

up3qbwjZs2BFA3Yk3gXfQw.text: Side-step the strip joints, dodge the massage place, turn the corner - don't go left!  That's a sex shop.  but right opposite is Yalla Yalla's first incarnation.  It's small, pokey but charming and the staff are swift and amiable.  We came here for a quick pre-show meal and fortunately avoided the rush - this place gets quite popular.  And with good reason too!  The food is fresh, flavoursome and delicious.  Well, the savory dishes are anyway.  I had Lokoz Meshoue - that's sarbass to you and me.  Grilled with citrus scented rice and a tomato and coriander sauce.  Dessert was a sickly disappointment 'though, too sweet for me.  Next time I'll stick with what I know and go for Backlawa.Great value for money.  I look forward to going again.

HSLywfjabOqf8t7VsT0XqQ.text: I had a birthday party here with about 12 of us...squished around a long table. Despite little room to move about in, the evening was perfect. We loved the sharing menu and we went with a suggested larger group set menu. This had meant that we'd tried a variety of the dishes and also we didn't spend umming and aaring about what to order. Great value for money. I would definitely recommend if you're after something fresh and something a little different.

DF7Rb0Dh7onGSBuCm2KD_w.text: Delicious and a nice wine list, service could be a bit more helpful and friendly. During my last visit to London I came here 3 times. Yalla Yalla is a cozy small restaurant located in an alley (small street) right off of lively Brewer Street in the SOHO area of the City of Westminster in London.  It sort of reminded me of the cozy neighborhood family owned restaurants I used to frequent in my hometown of San Francisco.The Baba Ghannouj was wonderful, nicely done with the right amount of smokiness  and creamy.  The Soujoc (spicy Lebanese sausages) was my favorite, although not a fan of liver I really liked the Sawda Djej it was tasty, very good, flavorful,  I would order it again. Hommus was perfect, I found the Batata Harra (spicy sauteed potatoes) to be good but not spicy enough they were more like breakfast potatoes, they were good but needed a little more kick to be described as "spicy".   Mixed Grill was another great dish, meat was perfect, juicy, nicely flavored. I definitely will return, the place is great for dine in or take out.

hj-bzXopTLf2cnbLJ6kwPw.text: Delicious food, good location, bit tight on the seating - I'm all for getting in as many people as want to be fed, but every time anyone got out of their seat they inadvertently knocked off the salt and pepper (or potentially drinks) from the neighbouring tables.

4zvbUjJVU5TzhUCs3azumw.text: Amazing food doesn't describe it. Try the falafel and puff pastry stuffed with mint and cheese - both divine.

yL5magtA5jsHegn_5Im_oA.text: The place is fairly claustrophobic, particularly the stairs down to the toilets, I hit my head on a ceiling several times while walking down those...The waiters are not very attentive and we set there waiting to order for good 10 mins without anyone noticing, while they were busy doing everything else other than what they are supposed to be doing - dealing with the clients.I had lamb shawarma and the taste was ok, but there were no sauces whatsoever, only a pile of marinated onions and a tiny bit of flatbread, how's that possible?! That's completely not they way I expect shawarma to be...The place seems quite popular so if you try to pop there after 18:00 most likely you'll find it packed, though to me it's completely overhyped.All in all - ok experience, but meh I've tried better...

qSxxJSjysVJgbVSV4dd3eA.text: Middle Eastern food is probably my favorite, so after a few days spent in Edingburgh sustaining on haggis, I had to get my fill of hummus. I wasn't disappointed. I came in pretty late - around midnight after catching a flick - the place was still pretty busy. It's a tiny joint that has perhaps 10 tables. Service is very polite and prompt and I ordered some baba ganoush, hummus and lam kofta kebab. I usually judge a middle eastern food place by the hummus (smooth, lots of tahini, little garlic bite) and this was was very good. The bread was fluffy and warm - overall comfort food.Prices are very reasonable - this is not a fancy restaurant - but clean, comfy and most importantly delicious.It's a bit hard to find being hidden in a dodgy alley in Soho and across from sticky sex shop - but don't let that be a deterrent - the food makes up for it ;)

lqFWgx9R94B_outTlSFzcg.text: Yalla Yalla was my introduction to Lebanese food, and they did not disappoint! On a Sunday afternoon, I came for lunch. The restaurant itself is not very large and the space was packed for 3pm, so I chose take-away. This was my first time sampling Baba Ghannouj, and it was delicious! The dish was rich and creamy, yet balanced by the drizzle of lemon juice. The pomegranate seeds and chopped mint were a nice addition, and really brought out the roasted flavors of the aubergine. This came accompanied by 3 medium-pieces of pita bread. Served warm, this mezze was more than a meal! Fairly-priced as well, Yalla Yalla is a great choice for Middle Eastern food.

oR1VbEWBYQ_OrSWCyGeWzw.text: I couldn't care less than whenever I go to Yalla Yalla, the staff seem to spill wine all over me. The reason for this is because their baba ghanoush is amazing.

bi8Hx854NnRBnHi-AF5OiQ.text: Cane here for lunch today and it was delicious, but service was very slow - about 50 mins from sitting down for lunch to getting 2 of our dishes and the rest of us had finished eating already. I'd definitely go back though when I wasn't in a rush. Portions are good, and great value for money. It's a tight squeeze in there but lovely for an intimate dinner!

zqeZc2aBpvQ53f_AarsGCg.text: Yalllllllllllllaaaaa! It's a good thing I like the food as much as the name, cause I just can't get enough of either. Tucked away on a wee back road on the seediest of Soho streets, this humble shop serves up some of the tastiest Beirut street food I've ever had the pleasure of noshing down. Ok, so maybe it's the only Beirutian street food I've ever had, but it has definitely piqued my interest in the cuisine of this country. At one point my darling dining partner actually said "I could bathe in this hummos. Dare I say... it's better than my Mum's... and my Mum's is the absolute best." 'nuf said.

OeR772cG6L_in9lEwEszzQ.text: O-M-G... The food here is ridiculous! And I mean ridiculously good! As soon as you walk into the modern yellow and wooden establishment your intuition tells you, your about to engage in an outer body food experience!Greeted by friendly staff, you are sat down with a mixed olive and pickles plate. Yum!!! Once you've had a few nibbles, you are given the menu, which might I say, is very very good! Lots of choice to tantalise the palette! Lamb, chicken, vegetables seasoned with excellent spices. I recommend the lamb Shawarma, which is succulent tender pieces of seasoned lamb, with rice, pitta, salad and garnish (the definition of heaven! Jheeze)! Compliment this with a fruity cocktail or simply a glass of still water to really appreciate all flavours. The portions sizes are big and you will most probably take a doggy bag, well, unless you suffer from tasty food glutton! Ha haPrices are extremely reasonable, average starter is a fiver, average main is £8. You can't go wrong really! Have a taste, you won't be disappointed!

-IFGZNSGFMQw4WZUDqDtCQ.text: The food was really good. Great place if you like ordering things to share. Really cute little restaurant. Great vibe. Great staff. The falafel was awesome!

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Falafel and haloumi

TO8JxFdG2Wo6pRYraHYcQA.text: More of a local lunch joint for Lebanese fare than a dinner destination. Hard communal benches weren't softened by the wine and good eats. That said, for what it is, it does it well. Just check your expectations of cozy ambiance at the door.

jjSqZwg9BAluocwuVFWtFg.text: On my first visit to London, I managed to go to Yalla Yalla 2 nights in a row. I really couldn't get enough. I grew up and lived in an area with AMAZING middle eastern food, and Yalla Yalla really hit the spot for my cravings. Fresh hummous, delicious pitas. Recommend the arayes (pita bread stuffed with minced lamb) and kibbe lahme (deep fried lamb and cracked wheat parcels filled with onions confit, minced meat and roasted pine nuts). The next time I'm back in London, I'll go for a main dish!Upside: Authentic LebaneseDownside: Small space with little seating

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Chicken livers
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Falafel
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Fried ground lamb

DzQFBwqN-v-cBdlvWZfRYg.text: Nice little spot in Soho. We ordered the baba ghannouj and the mixed grill. Everything was fresh and really tasty. A little pricey for dinner, but would make a nice date night. Prices looked more reasonable for lunch.

M0pz3T7OSXHTaUIqiZWavw.text: This is one of my absolute favorite places to eat in London. Have been here four times... I love the cozy atmosphere! Almost feels like you popped into a friends home for dinner. The service attentive and usually fast as there's often a queue of people waiting outside. They have a pretty extensive menu for a reasonable price. My fiancé and I usually share 2-3 appetizers and a main... We never make it to dessert. Haven't tried the cocktails but they sound interesting. Can't wait to come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Sausage
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

dLVkVOkTOt6EdJcsbyueQQ.text: It a tiny little place but quite cozy. The food tastes good but it definitely foes not taste authentic. We ordered falafel, baby ganoush and shish taouk dinner. Everything had good flavor but the shish taouk definitely lagged the Arabic/lebanese flavor.We were there with our two toddlers who were being very mannered the whole time. However the waitress seemed to be very agitated by thepresence of their push cart. She was neither friendly nor approachable. You'll like the food but don't go there with an expectation of having an authentic Arabic food

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Shish taouk
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Falafel

QiV30ZbBqz-TS_trRfQRvQ.text: This is some of the best Lebanese food I have ever had. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because the restaurant itself was crowded and not the most comfortable, but it is a quaint little restaurant that would be really nice if it weren't as busy as when I was there. There were constantly people coming in for take away so that would be a great option.Highly recommend the hot sauce and garlic sauce that comes on the side. We had the fattoush salad, which was a very generous portion and really delicious - highly recommend. We also had the chicken skewers with rice and hummus with chicken, which were both really good and enough to split between two people. Definitely planning to go back or have takeaway from here sometime soon!!

D4Vrrx4ZXB184cKDpwYJ6Q.text: Very tasty food! We ordered the lamb shoulder and the sea bass to share and were not disappointed, the flavours were good. However the portions of meat were very small, less then 1 serving of lamb in the first dish and 2 mini fillets of sea bass. Service was definitely underwhelming. We were ignored a few times when we requested additional drinks. All in all an okay no frills spot to eat.

cyAgrJ6QNOSN8D1X6y0keA.text: Good place situated in a little alleyway right next to some shops that remind you that Soho was the red light district for a long time.Usually swing by for the wraps for take away which I really like.  I love the spicy sauce as well as the garlic/yogurt dip.  I always have to ask for more.I have also had their normal mezzo dishes once before and was pretty satisfied.  I like the flavors in their food and for London it's not too bad price-wise.  It's also a great place for vegetarian folks as many of the items don't contain any meat.The interior is quite cozy.  They have a few small tables outside as well.  I'm willing to give them 4 stars...BUT there is a small caveat.  They have a tendency to mess up the wrap orders.  Once we didn't get the right number of wraps and once my lamb and kofta ended up being a kofta and halloumi wrap.  So...just check your order.

Y607-PyhAI7OMqDNy9_Ctg.text: What a fantastic little place. Great for vegetarians it's got a good choice of meat dishes too. Just one small room that holds about 20 people. Staff a bit hit and miss but most are very helpful if very relaxed. The food is amazing. Usual suspects of falafel, hummus, tabbouleh etc. but I especially liked the little lamb parcels with pine nuts and tahini. A lovely romantic little place.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Small plate sharers
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Small plate sharers

OgN54_bsCODBj8suSwvx-w.text: Great place to eat if you're a vegetarian or as in my case, a friend who's a vegetarian. That way i didn't have to compromise with a strictly veggie place and order myself a nice Meshoue. He was happy with his falafel, I was happy with my lamb skewers and we both went out quite full.The place is pretty small and cosy and you will definitely have to hear what other people have to say to their comrades. Well, we went for the feast and weren't exactly sharing nuclear secrets so we didn't mind the close seating.My advice is to go with someone, order a few mezze dishes, a couple of mains and I guarantee you'll be in for a real treat.

Q-BqOtF0t-QE4cbqnPjRhg.text: They should call this place Yummy Yummy.  The mezze and entrees were terrific.  We ordered a hummus, arayes, falafel and raw kibbi.  For the main entrees, we had the chicken sharwma and lamb kabob.  The arayes was probably may fave of all the mezzas.  Crispy and sweet with flavorful lamb and pine nuts - yummy (there I go again).The raw kibbi was served with a lot of marinated onions and parsley.  I've usually had it served with just raw onion.  While good, I found it to be slightly underflavored.The chicken sharwma was very tasty.  The lamb was good, but I found it slightly cooked to much for me (it was medium).Overall, even though this place is small, it has an intimate feel and the food overall was very good.  Check it out, you'll enjoy it.

cwLetV7ySGkRVgD162um7w.text: I went here on Saturday with a friend who I'd not seen for a couple of months and we had always wanted to try this place. I think we slightly annoyed the staff as we were chatting so much and each time they came to take our order, we hadn't had the chance to look at the menu, maybe not but that's the impression I got. The food was very tasty and we chose and shared the right amount - 5 mezzo dishes - Lebanese sausages, houmous, baba ganoush, calamari, fried shrimp and whitebait (least favourite dish), halloumi and filo parcels of feta cheese (amazing!) We had a berry Martini and Turkish Delight cocktail which were delicious especially the former which you could taste the alcohol in whereas you couldn't in the latter. I was quite surprised when the bill came at the price as it seemed quite pricey and was nearly £60. Friendly and quick service. Handy location, just offer Brewer Street and close to Old Compton St in the heart of Soho.

5fe_z-AgRhE8DgmK8WRn-g.text: Fantastic little joint. The chicken livers with pomegranate was fabulous - highly recommended.

Q6dRDeZ7MP2nEH_ipAgXgA.text: Truly fantastic: enjoyed lunch while visiting friends in London who recommended this gem.  Between three of us we ate hummus with lamb (insanely good); creamy baba ghanouj; a really nice fattoush salad; chicken livers (blew my mind with their vinegary goodness); a delish grilled cheese; and the seafood/eggplant fried mezze which was remarkable as well.  We arrived on the early side (11am-ish) and had no problem bagging a table, but it clearly gets quite a lunch crowd.Can't recommend it enough!

58h5JStTIRRtqHWPfw_V2g.text: What a great first experience with lebanese food - absolutely delicious.I had hinted of being extremely hungry and therefore we came here. It was a Wednesday night and arriving at 8:30 we were seated about ten til 9.In two we got 4 mezze (baba ghannouj,  falafel, fattoush, and manaee'sh cheese) and one main (mixed grill) - all to share. We got one mezze too many (wasn't a big fan of the fattoush - personal taste). Everything was so fresh and tasty - my favorites were definitely the baba ghannouj and manaee'sh cheese.This location is quite small and doesn't take reservations - so a slight wait should be expected - but it is well worth it!

VhJJufSAs0iLrwlqWK3a0A.text: When I think about my trip to Beirut, I can't help think of Kebab-ji!There are a few locations around London and this has got to be the tiniest one.  Because it's so cramped, they asked us to wait outside until our table was ready.  They were quite nice about it and even offered us something to drink while we wait.It is really cozy here!  I felt like I could've reached over and grabbed food off the table next to us but it's all part of the fun.  We started out with the hummous and cheesy bread thing.  Hummous was great - the cheesy bread thing - give it a pass.  I never salt my food and I had to sprinkle a bit on it.For our mains, we had the chicken and man... chicken can't get any better than this.  It was delicious and reminded me a lot of my trip to Beirut - so it's the real deal.

5ruYdPy7EzickW-DFBZJCA.text: The location is off of a side street with very limited seating.  Pretty good middle eastern food, service was good, and the food came out promptly.  The main downside is the seating situation.  It causes people to loom over you while you're eating.

mvveKngqj5pA6rmusI2SAQ.text: This is a lovely little restaurant tucked away in Oxford Circus. There's several locations and I like this one the best. It's got a European feel to it with it's blackboard walls and intimate seatings. It was a very busy Friday night but we managed to sit inside after eating outside for a bit. We ordered a whole range of dishes but what really stood out for me were the pastries and halloumi. A great place to go with just your significant other or a group of friends, but do be warned it can be a long wait if you don't book in advance.

gQEfZlTF2QdjhlKM4JlcFg.text: I had this review drafted as 3 stars after our first visit, but I'm now content to bump it up to 4. Yalla Yalla is a tiny little nook that serves a limited range of tasty Lebanese treats. I get my Lebanese street food kicks from Tasty Lebanon on the other end of Soho (do check out my review for them for more deets) but sometimes you want a little more variety (read: not kebab), and that's where Yalla Yalla steps in.First things first: is it as good? Eh. Item per item, I think the tabbouleh, hummus, and falafel are better at TL. However, Yalla Yalla offers some 'real food' options that will knock your socks off. Lamb anything? Stellar. Do make sure you give their specials a go: their lamb chops with pomegranate molasses and aubergine salad was the best meal I've had in months, with the lamb slightly pink, ridiculously rich, beautifully seasoned, and offset by smoky, tangy aubergine dip studded with pomegranate seeds and the tang of pomegranate molasses. Y u m.Other things are a bit of a disappointment. None of the starters really stood out; the platters (we opted for veggie) are the best value to share and come with a range of mezze. The chicken livers, much touted by some reviewers, failed to shine for me: they were soupy, lacked any redeeming browned bits, and were frankly a little stale. Speaking of stale, the baklava certainly is, or at least it was the one time we tried it.Also, without any bearing on the review, their seats are hella uncomfortable, and you're either sitting a little too low or way too high. Awkward. I get that they want to cram in as many seats as possible into a tiny footprint but that doesn't really make things right.Final point: portions feel a little skimpy for the money compared to similar offerings, especially in the starters.

JLuw8cEcrYF-jnivXEeB4A.text: We had dinner here last night.  The hummus and shawarma, kibbe lahme and mixed grill were all delicious.  We were fortunate to get a table before things got very busy(although it is a tight fit).  The price was also very reasonable.

y5xQoLGlPYWpfcYHbht-cA.text: I loved the food so much. The grills, hummus and fattoush are fantastic. You can easily find grills done well but you can rarely find hummus and fattoush done the traditional Lebanese way. Five stars indeed.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Hummus

PS_AifQiM3C-ZZdTV_4F4g.text: I had some of the best Middle Eastern food I've ever had at this tiny place in Soho. The Kastaleta (grilled lamb) was fantastic. It was flavorful and tender. The smoky zucchini on  the side was the perfect addition. The grilled shrimp, chicken shawarma, and hommos were also excellent. If you're near Piccadilly or Leicester Square this place is worth seeking out.

_c8wzHhJ56Z5DR408L_hbg.text: So I went to the restaurant at 9:45 last night - well before it closes at 11pm. When I arrived,I was told the kitchen closed at 10. I was obviously confused since the restaurant closes at 11, but reminded them it was 9:45 still. Their response: "the kitchen is closed." Not cool.

A0Q_dG9x_c8xPZSIzMpt4Q.text: Cozy and romantic place in Soho, great for a dinner date. Very popular as well. Went there on a Saturday night and it was packed. Not too noisy, though. The food is Beirut street food, I wish I could have tasted the whole menu. A lot of kafta and shawarma, but also other exciting things. I had a slow cooked lamb stew which name I will never remember. You'll know it when you see the menu. Very nice with a tomato/bell pepper sauce. The staff is busy but very friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Slow cooked lamb stew with baby aubergines.

Dsnh9HGt4J2uM4pJYKspeA.text: When I travel, I check out Lebanese food. The service wasn't the greatest and the good was ok. I expected better.

QKuWxN3HMbm2g5lIYd8CvQ.text: FRIGGING UNCOMFORTABLE CHAIRS/STOOLS. I popped to Yalla Yalla for lunch last Thursday: the room is extremely small and it's more of  take-out place I'd say, even though they managed to squeeze in a handful of tables. Ours was right in front of the door, which was for some reason kept open with a stool. We sat down and I had no space whatsoever where to put my coat and handbag (I don't mind leaving my stuff on the floor but...there's no space on the floor. And it being a stool I couldn't hang anything on the back of a chair either). Particularly peeved at how uncomfortable it was. That said, the food was really nice. My friend ordered a wrap and I had lamb cutlets with an aubergine and pomegranate sort of salsa. I couldn't spot any aubergine in there, but the lamb was very very nice nonetheless. I could have eaten double that. It was also a bit difficult to get the staff's attention, which is weird considering how small the place is, and our table was nearly in front of the counter where people queue to order/pay. I think one of the tables against the wall would have made for a better experience, but alas we didn't get one. So I'll have to leave it at that.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

_iTT36qb958zC3HQ0pfMwg.text: I've been to Yalla Yalla ever since they opened in late 2008. I loved the food from the beginning and I also liked the coziness that this place radiates. My favourites are mixed mezze plates for lunch, their falafels, the chicken shawarma wrap (with garlic & chilli sauces)...and an absolute staple is their apple/mint/ginger lemonade.Unlike in the beginning, it is now practically impossible to simply show up at Yalla Yalla and expect to find a seat. What I've resorted doing is to take said items to go and sit down at the nearby Soho Square instead.There's one pet-peeve I have with this place: their staff rarely smiles and seems always stressed and overworked...if it weren't for the delicious treats I get here, I wouldn't have the urge to come back here that often.

LcXhAdfk4ZMBLyPG5lj_sQ.text: Loved this little hole in the wall place. Amazing hummus and delicious vegetarian options. Small place and not much seating so get there early.

jsPQVALYQ04Wlt_lA3JRYA.text: My first experience with what I would assume was an authentic Lebanese kitchen. One of the participant of the SoHo food fare was Lebanese and in her opinion it was right on the money.We had two dishes: Baba Ghannoujj and Soujoc, and they were both brilliant. Just brilliant. The smoothness of the Baba and the spiciness of the Soujoc sausages was perfect.This place is a must-visit in SoHo is small and intimate - almost secret. And according to the prices on the chart a bargain!I'm coming nexttime I'm in London.===Disclaimer; this was a stop on a SoHo food safari-thing, so the review may seem rather slim but we only had a few items.

eqcoKGKk_T9PBKa0E-s6Fw.text: very small venue. Welcoming staff, more of a cafe atmoshere than restaurant.The dishes were expensive for the small amounts that they were but this is soho so probably not as much  value for money as the outskirts.The dishes were tasty and i loved their fried white bait,calamari and prawns. They had a problem with their grill so couldnt have the mixed grill so chose the lamb shwarma. Not thin slices like in a shwarma takeaway but thick pieces that were tasty but  salty. I enjoyed their homemade lemonade and pomegranate juice

HIGFUkvO7hF1v4Ow1t09xw.text: I was very disappointed by the false advertisement the menu offers and what you actually get served, the misconception of the order is absolutely not satisfying to the Custemer and what I I payed for and what I ordered, with some of the servers not even understating what your saying, and the manager when I discussed with him the issue, he didn't want to do anything and offered me to order and pay for another one to get what I ordered the first time, This is one of the worst places I feel I got ripped off, my personal advice look for another place that serves better Quility food

syEUPkD0sZS61Ceh3Z_X8g.text: Tiny restaurant, huge amount of love for it! This is lebanese food done right. Tucked away in a little street in Soho, the place is small but cozy and bright. I have enjoyed rainy afternoons in here and no matter how crowded it gets and how difficult to squeeze between the tables, the atmosphere is always friendly and the decor is cute. There have been times so busy that newcomers just make the rounds and hover near crowded tables in the hopes that you and your coat and bag will evacuate the tiny table and give them somewhere to sit and I don't blame them, the place really is great. The food is inexpensive and delicious!! It's the perfect place to order lots of small dishes to share with a friend and just have a good time.I like to get a lot of little dishes to share and one main. There are lots of great small dishes on the menu, from the standard hummus, which is decent, to my favourites the yummy kibbe lahme (minced lamb and wheat) and the delicious arayes (pita bread with minced lamb). The tabbouleh is not to my taste because it has more onions than I like but others might not mind.They also serve soujoc, a lebanese sausage that I like and don't find everywhere, but this one is just passable and I wasn't a big fan. The rest of the food more than makes up for it though.  My favorite mains are  the classic chicken shawarma and the slow cooked lamb casserole is very tender and fantastic too and I recommend it wholeheartedly.A trip here for me is never complete without a pot of perfect mint tea to share and chat over. This place is a gem and I never mind the crush in here because I'm so happy with everything that is on my tiny table:) Get here early if you can though!

_xWcVkBNWFLNzNiV5-jSRg.text: Oh dear. We had a bit of an iffy metal at Yalla Yalla which is normally freaking fabulous and totally awesome. The hummus shawarma and grilled halloumi were both quite good. But ...The fattoush was salty. Like, really really salty. The kofta was good but sat on a very paltry bed of rice.  It just looked and felt a bit cheap. The chicken shawarma was not good. The meat was not flavoursome but boring and bland. Again, the pieces sat on top of a very thin bed of rice.  I'm sure it was just an off day but it's never a good sign when you bring friends after raving about YY, only to get this.  Hopefully, it was just a one off.

i3vuEEl7PmvSxUQpHXIkQA.text: Visited this place based on Yelp reviews and our group had a very good experience! The reviews and ratings are well deserved!

LNa3qg58ZRInLhpjxEcoug.text: A little restaurant in a little side alley. Good service and even better food. I had the sawda djej (chicken liver) and the kastaleta (lamb chops) and both were delicious

hGgYCaXm0az0hTwN7rfROg.text: Yalla Yalla has had raving reviews, and the consistent line outside the door of their tiny shop is testament to how popular it is. My family and I waited an hour and a half, so I highly recommend you make reservations or come at non-peak hours!For starters, we had the baba ghanouj, spicy potatoes, and the deep fried seafood plate. The baba ghanouj had an amazing charcoal flavor, which was elevated by the pomegranate seeds, lemon, and mint leaves. We sopped up every last bit of the dip with the warm pita bread, and was still craving more! The spicy potatoes reminded me of breakfast potatoes in the US, but I did like how crispy they were without being greasy. They also had a delicious spicy seasoning that made it unique. The seafood plate is also a great deal, with calamari, shrimp, smelt, and eggplant that had a light fry on it. I loved that it was paired with a yogurt dip that cut the grease and heaviness of a deep-fried dish.Next, I had the chicken shawarma, which was a little disappointing. The chicken was a little dry and salty enough to keep me chugging water for hours after the meal. I loved the basmati rice though, which was fragrant and fluffy. My brother had the shish taouk, which was marinated chicken breast cubes on a skewer. His meat looked much more tender and well-cooked than mine, so if you're looking for a chicken dish I recommend this one instead! My parents both had the sea bass, but were doubtful about whether the fish really was sea bass. It was lightly pan-fried, then covered with a delicious tomato sauce. I really appreciated the freshness of the ingredients, but the food had a few missteps along the way that took away from the meal as a whole.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Chicken shawarma
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Sea bass
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Deep fried seafood with yogurt dip

9kRRk84MDjC5mMFViT0dYA.text: Of all the foods across the globe, Lebanese is by far my favourite cuisine. I love the fact that you can order lots of different plates of food which can be shared amongst friends, allowing you to nibble a bit of this and that - and importantly allowing you not to get food envy across the table!I headed down to Yalla Yalla, located just behind Oxford Street on Monday evening for a catch up with an old work colleague. I arrived a little earlier, and as guests aren't seated until the whole party arrives, sat down to wait for my companion at the bar whilst enjoying a glass of apple, mint and ginger lemonade and taking in my surroundings.The vibe of the restaurant is very noisy and lively, owing to the fact that you sit on long communal tables (think Wagamamas/Flesh & buns) so it makes it a great place to socialise in big groups. Once we were seated, we got ahead with ordering a selection of dishes to share, which arrive as they are cooked rather all at the same time - for this reason I didn't get a snap of some of the dishes as I was too busy scoffing to remember!'Tabboule'  - my go-to Lebanese dish a salad comprised of chopped parsley, mint, spring onion, tomato, olive oil, lemon juice and cracked wheat. A little lacking in in lemon juice- the best tabuloueh, for me, packs a real zing!'Halloum meshoue' - chunks of grilled halloumi cheese served with with tomato, black olives, fresh mint dressed in olive oil.Hommos - deliciously creamy and very moreish!The Chicken Rakakat (delicious fragrant fried pastry filled with marinated chicken, garlic and harrisa) were the star of the show and the Falafel served with tahini and garlic youghurt sauce were moist and delicious.  Sadly these were devoured before I got the chance to photograph them - but I can vouch for how delicious they are! All the above, plus two drinks came to £15 each which I think is great value - highly recommend if you're looking for an informal lunch or dinner venue!

6H_uSssqWSm6Uv1iy99_6w.text: Another place that has been on my list to try for nearly a year! I love Lebanese food so when my friend told me to check it out last year I of course noted it down! A friend and I booked at table on a weekday for 6pm -  a very small restaurant (a bit cramped feeling) there didn't seem any need to book however by 6.30 it was pretty full! Although the main dishes look amazing (particularly interested in trying LAMB SHAWARMA - Grilled thin slices of marinated lamb, grilled tomato, sumac and parsley onion salad with basmati vermicelli rice & KASTALETA - Charcoal grilled marinated lamb cutlets with grilled  baby aubergine, spring onion and red pepper puree) we opted for the mezze to share so we could try plenty of dishes! We went for 5 dishes; baba ghannouj, ,mince lamb parcels, feta and halloumi parcels, sauteed potatoes and chicken parcels along with a bottle of Lebanon white. EVERYTHING was delicious. Impressed with baba ghannouj and the white. I can't remember the cost however not unreasonable but not great value. Service was good. I will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

-g0ZdbaN8TtclNSL9gQPmg.text: Love love love - get the hummus with lamb, the chicken wings and any of the wraps. The tabbouleh is also amazing. The only hit and miss from me is the fattoush salad which can have too much sumac and a little wilted but 9 / 10 it's been great. I just love it here and wish I worked closer!

lswPW6dvPePFGRA5B0awqg.text: Every time I go there, I always find consistently fresh and tasty Lebanese food - from baba ghanouj, fattoush, samboussek jibne and batenjan mehshi.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

jpFxtnno5AubLoEYpawDcg.text: My friends and I found this place as we were heading home after a few drinks. Someone had told me about this place before and I really wanted to like it.I do like the decor, and I like that they have some sandwiches on display. But I don't like much else.We made our order and were waiting for it to come out. The sandwich was on display and just needed to be heated. It took a good 15 minutes for them to heat and wrap 4 sandwiches. They also rudely asked us to wait outside as we were crowding them. The staff was generally rude, as when I asked about other items they had, they were rude and told me that what's on display was all they had left. I understand that it was late and might be the end of their work day, but it wouldn't kill them to be nicer.Then the sandwich: dry meat, very underwhelming. Maybe they are better as table service? I don't know.

rHcsj19qhpFBduahwod7vw.text: If you're in London and in the Soho ares this is a must try middle astern Lebanese family restaurant. Service is amazing and the place is really clean and easy to find on yelp and google maps. Food was made fresh in house and as tasty as you'd expect.Must try the Lebanese strong coffee before you leave to give you some boost to walk  :)Definitely recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Marinated olives
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Homos
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Tabouleh

FExkKpTPy-h_qLG8HkYmBg.text: I go to this location at 10:20pm to order a couple of chicken shawarmas for take away and as soon as I got in the lady tells me that they are closed. I'd give a zero if I could. What's the point of saying you're open till 11pm. I won't be coming back to try this place.

K6le7RH0E9taZ8aoiKFLcQ.text: Stopped here while in town on holiday/business with a friend who was raving about it.   The spot itself is small and very intimate.  Perfect for a date or small gathering of friends.   We literally ordered every small plate on the menu and gobbled all of it down.  My personal favorite being the hummus with chicken.   So very tasty.   Also the chicken wings were really good!  Definitely check YY out if you are in the neighborhood!

F04TVIQvxeWqJ5RoP__YMg.text: We were really disappointed by Yalla Yalla.  We ordered the lamb/beef wrap and falafel wrap.  The meat was not all the way cooked and there was no flavor to the falafel. It wasn't horrible, but we wouldn't go there again.

WfjRpqdR1rDLOywu6crsOQ.text: Such a cute little hole in the wall restaurant. This is a great place to stop by for lunch or dinner that doesn't break the bank. We arrived here at 8pm on a Monday night and were seated immediately. After ordering, it took quite a while to get our food to the table but it seemed like only 2 people ran the store.A salad and bread are given to everyone as a starter. The salad is refreshing and light, featuring mint and cucumbers and a light balsamic. It's a great way to start off the meal.We ordered a fish, a lamb, and a chicken plate. Each came with rice, bread, and pickled vegetables. Everything was delicious! The chicken was definitely my favorite. You can tell how freshly made everything is and how good the produce they use is. Overall, this is a great option for lunch or dinner if you don't mind waiting longer to get your food.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

KQU05tO3F0cPesg1WvpR2g.text: Went here for a late night dinner, almost close to 10:00pm. The ambiance is very traditional. Service was decent and food was pretty good! We had the Hommos and Falafel to start with. Really wanted to try the Batenjan Mehshi but they had ran out it so we settled for the Chicken Shawarma. We enjoyed our meal and they didn't really rush us! They were so kind, they even packed us some Baklava on the house as we headed out :)

AKGh6mcrxQQ6ecM7yOFPhQ.text: Great Lebanese restaurant in central London, just a few steps away from the busy Oxford street. Vast selection of small plates to share with company, delicious lebanese main dishes and decent prices.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom

MU2sPXvVCGHZCWZUxvIS5Q.text: Delicious hummus (£5), falafel (~£6), and pita bread (complimentary with side orders). Not crazy expensive given London prices but just a touch overpriced if you think about it (coming from an American standpoint where you'd get a whole falafel wrap with hummus for $6). Also had their slow cooked lamb main which came with rice which was okay but not the best so I wouldn't recommend it. They have special lunch wraps which I think are a good deal and they have a card so if you get like 9 or something, you'll get a free one.

4tc0hYlIdN0q9mqhYzR4Wg.text: It's eh at best...we went for a late lunch and despite having an extensive wrap menu, we were told that they didn't have any. For starters, we shared hummus, babaganoush, and falafel. The babaganoush was not smoky enough for my taste and the complimentary pita was straight from a bag and chewy. For our mains, we got the chicken kebab and a chicken/lamb mixed kebab plate. While the chicken was tender, it was nothing particular special. Probably any other place it would be fine but the competition for this kind of cuisine in London is pretty stiff, hence the three stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Mains: Chicken kebab + chicken/lamb combo kebab
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Mezzes: hummus, falafel, babaganoush and pita

3UskTfyuvwhoXljt04B1Zw.text: Lots of under £10 options for a light lunch - most actually fall in the under £6 category - so you can splurge and treat yourself to many tastes. For this price point you get a lot of atmosphere. Super cute cafe with real decor and nice staff.Hubby and I grabbed a mana'eesh lamb which was tasty - 4 slices of bread with a thin spread of lamb on top, covered with slices of red onion, pomegranates and pomegranate molasses. But it was definitely more of snack than a meal. It came with some pita bread which was not that good. We also got some arabica coffee - a turkish style coffee - which was really nice and strong. *** pro tip: though there are menus on the table they have a huge chalkboard wall of take-away wraps. Sadly we didn't notice this in time.If you're looking for a place in Soho to chill out it's pretty good. There was someone working on their laptop the entire time.

photos.caption: Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. mana'eesh lamb 6
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. July 28 menu

Uq5gxleT-1ZlxKwFcXXC0Q.text: Great tasting food that won't cost you an arm and a leg. It's not necessarily cheap though either. I'm a fan of the chicken shawarma, hummus, and baba ghannouj. That's enough food for two people to share. I've also gone the route of ordering two mains and sharing a starter. The place is located in a smaller walk way, just off a busy Soho street. I've seen DeliverRoo folks grab food from here, so I assume they do delivery. It sometimes get crowded, so you may have to wait for tables to clear. Coming after 1:30, you should have no problem with a lunch crowd.

Photo of Yalla Yalla - London, United Kingdom. Baba ghannouj

9HZzTbamJ1Wz9s2innXE_g.text: Great food, great service, one of our favorites. Perfect to share plates. Love the hummus, babaganouz, mixed grill plate.

Ii9X9tGtpyutFjqzjZp5VQ.text: Fanastic Food in a charming little spot just off Oxford Street. Very reasonable. Even the kids loved it.

_ngV6qxqSVc3w_1l9n6d7A.text: Fresh and healthy ingredients, rich flavors, friendly and helpful servers, good prices, and a welcome world away from the surrounding Soho scene.

PV5NjDthQvbhAj-D_pT2kw.text: Food was excellent! But the lady in blond was so mean and luck of hospitality. One of the worst experience ever. She just ruined my entire lunch break at this Restaurant. Another lady in black hair was nice and kind thought. Only wish the one with blond hair is not working here, I'd love to come back this Restaurant..... Disappointed.

u26_NBWp8_KMb2LBowoghA.text: Tiny place with comfort food. Huge portions and friendly service. I ordered a shawarma which came as chicken, rice, salad and a piece of bread on top of it. They also served garlic sauce on the side. Food was good, a bit modernised for the city I feel. Should have come with some Arabic pickles and tahina as well.
